Step-by-step Preparation of Medicine

Step 1: Check the Prescribed Medicine

Make sure that the medication order is correctly read and interpreted. The following items must be checked:

  • Method of preparation of the drug
  • Quantity
  • Administration route
  • Shelf life after preparation of the medicine

And if applicable:

  • What solvent should be used?
  • Which diluent is appropriate to use?

For this, you can read the Parenteral Handbook for more information.

Step 2: Writing the Administration Label

After checking the medication order, the assignment must be converted into a delivery label. It is best to have this in printed form.

The following information must be included on the label:

  • Date and time of preparation
  • Name of the medication in accordance with the assignment
  • Dosage of the medicine
  • Space for 2 initials
  • If applicable, name and quantity of the diluent or solvent

Note: Avoid abbreviations as much as possible to prevent misinterpretations.

Step 3: Calculate the Correct Amount

Calculate the correct amount and dosage of the medicine to be administered and double check it.

Step 4: Disinfection and Hygiene Measures

Provide a clean and well-organized worktop and disinfect using 70% alcohol. Allow the worktop to air dry.

  • Provide clean work clothes and gloves if necessary
  • Do not wear jewelleries
  • Disinfect the hands with hand alcohol according to the hand hygiene guidelines of your own hospital

Step 5: Collect and Prepare Material

  • Ampoule or vial with the medicine
  • Syringe, choose the volume of the syringe based on the medication order
  • Connector pieces
  • Gauze
  • Delivery label
  • Needles and needle cup
  • Gloves
  • Disinfectant alcohol, 70%
  • Parenteral or package leaflet manual

If applicable

  • Solvent
  • Thinner

Step 6: Preparing Medicine and Signing

Note the following aspects:

  • Finish the preparation, labelling and signing of the medicine in 1 time to avoid any distraction
  • Provide a clean worktop with every preparation
  • Disinfect the vials and the neck of ampoules with 70% alcohol
  • Carefully follow the instructions in the Parenteral Handbook and the package leaflet

Note: Paraphernalia in the nursing department can be prepared up to 8 hours in advance.

Step 7: Check and Sign by Second Person

It is necessary for a second person (colleague) to check the prepared medication.

This second person goes through the following information:

  • Proper medication order
  • Proper medicine, so keep the used ampoules or vials
  • Correct dosage of the drug
  • Shelf life or expiration date of the medicine
  • Correct calculation
  • If applicable, correct solvent or correct amount of the diluent and the correct method of preparation

Subsequently, the second person can also sign the administration label. In the discovery of errors, the prepared product is immediately destroyed.

Risks

Many errors can occur during the preparation of medicines, both when preparing and administering. Double checking the medications is necessary to ensure that risks are minimized.
